_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Conducting a Minimum System Safety Evaluation gap assessment associated with the industry recognized standard (IIAR Standard 9) for existing ammonia refrigeration systems.
  --  Reviewing and auditing the risk management and prevention policies to ensure they are maximizing the facilitys efforts at limiting the risks associated with handling anhydrous ammonia.

--  First Aid Procedures
  --  Emergency Medical Treatment Procedures
  --  Evacuation Plans + Assembly Areas
  --  Description for Handling Small Ammonia Releases
  --  Details of Outside Assistance Available 
  --  Incident Command System
  --  Initial and Refresher Training

Evacuation drills are also organized and conducted annually by the EHS Department to supplement the training received by all employees at the facility.  As facility management strives to improve safety at the facility, evaluations are documented with suggested improvements, and other observations from the drills.


PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Danone North America has worked to address safety issues as they arise in a continued effort to ensure a safe working environment.  Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Committee Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

Danone North America, with support from contractors and consultants entrenched in the ammonia refrigeration industry, strives to ensure a safe working environment at the facility for all employees, guests, and visitors.  The facility also plans to improve safety as follows:

  --  Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.
  --  Participation of key personnel in industry recommended training classes to ensure the facility is aware of evolving industry standards and techniques used to encourage a safety culture at the facility.
  --  Conducting routine RMP / PSM Committee meetings to ensure any issues identified by facility personnel, refrigeration contractors, or consultants are discussed and addressed.
  --

closed-loop system without any regular emissions or releases.  Any leaks / unanticipated ammonia odors are noted and repaired immediately.


FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPAs RMP regulation defines accident as the following: 

The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

  --  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
  --  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).

An investigation into the facilitys accident history revealed that there have been no significant ammonia releases over the past five years (February 2019  February 2024) that exceeded the Federal Reportable Quantity of 100 pounds or the California state requirement mandating immediate reporting of any release or threatened release of a hazardous material.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from an ammonia release at the facility.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Danone North America facility and is maintained by the Environmental Health & Safety department.  It is based on Cal-OSHAs requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220).

The Emergency Action Plan contains procedures detailing how the facility will react to accidental ammonia releases and other emergencies such as fires, earthquakes, power outages, etc.  This policy has been coordinated with the local emergency service agencies including:  the City of Industry Fire Department, and the Los Angeles County Fire Department - Hazardous Materials Division.

The facilitys Emergency Action / Response Policy includes the following elements:

  --  Key Facility Personnel and Responsibilities
  --  Outside Agency Notification Contact Information
  --  Detailed Action Plans for Internal Departments

the prescribed inspections / testing / and maintenance tasks that are conducted on all refrigeration system components + auxiliary systems.  This policy was recently updated in accordance with the recognized industry standard, IIAR Standard 6.  The facility utilizes in-house Utilities mechanics for Daily Ammonia System Rounds (w/ log sheet) to monitor system parameters and to alert the refrigeration contractor if any conditions are out of range.  The contractor is also assigned the duties to conduct the weekly, monthly, semi-annual, and annual preventative maintenance tasks.

The Danone North America ammonia refrigeration system has many safety design features including ammonia leak detectors, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, emergency stop controls, and an Emergency Refrigerant Control Box.  In addition, all pressure-rated vessels are equipped with mechanical pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation to ensure the integrity of the vessel and associated piping is protected.

Much of the safety of the refrigeration system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  The Danone North America facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically outline requirements for the design and operation of ammonia refrigeration system.  In addition to routine patrols and inspections at the facility by the security company, the facility has Utilities personnel on-site 24/7 who monitor for any abnormal conditions.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition change that occurs within the system are phase changes, as ammonia is cycled through various stages of liquid and vapor, similar to the refrigerant in a household refrigerator.  The refrigeration system is a

Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential gaps in compliance and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

Several departments within the facility (Maintenance / Utilities, Environmental Health & Safety, and Engineering) as well as outside resources (Ammonia Refrigeration Contractor, and a Risk Management Consultant) comprise the facility's PSM/RMP Committee that meets on a routine basis (typically monthly) to ensure the appropriate and ongoing implementation of the various elements of the programs.  Discussions range from outstanding corrective action items, to planned design changes to the ammonia system, to changes in plant personnel, to reviewing evacuation drill results, etc.  Significant issues that may be identified are brought to plant leadership to ensure appropriate resources are allocated.

The ultimate goal for Danone North Americas PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid adverse impacts to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate the refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern the ammonia refrigeration system, as well as the broader ammonia refrigeration industry throughout the country.  In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the Fire Departments from the City of Industry and Los Angeles County (Hazardous Materials Division).

The ammonia refrigeration system and the associated safety features were designed in accordance with contemporary codes and standards.  The PSM/RMP Committee also routinely reviews Recognized and Generally Accepted Good Engineering Practices (RAGAGEP) for the ammonia refrigeration industry to ensure that the facility is maintained, and appropriate plans / adjustments are made based on evolving industry standards.

One of the primary policies within the RMP & PSM programs is the Mechanical Integrity program that details

orators (inside penthouses) + associated valve groups and piping.

Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to move heat from product in the cold storage zones and secondary coolants (glycol) to the outside atmosphere.  When heat is absorbed by the liquid ammonia, it vaporizes (changes phase), and is then compressed by the compressors.  The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers (outside), where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor to the atmosphere, causing the ammonia to condense to a high pressure liquid, which drains by gravity back into the High Pressure Receiver.

Multiple auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the ammonia refrigeration system including:  ammonia leak detection, pressure relief system w/ water diffusion tank, emergency refrigerant control box, auto purger to remove non-condensible gasses, and a refrigeration control system.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed for the Danone North America facility to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant ammonia release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Policies developed for the PSM/RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, standard operating procedures, training, management of change + pre-startup safety review, mechanical integrity (inspections / testing / maintenance), hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsible parties for the facility to ensure upkeep and implementation of each policy within the RMP & PSM programs.  Compliance

ograms for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68), and the California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) program (CCR Title 19, Div. 2, Chapter 4.5).  The EHS + Maintenance Departments have the primary responsibilities for implementation of the RMP and PSM policies aimed at reducing the hazards associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Danone North America facility is located at 18275 Arenth Avenue, in the City of Industry, California. The facility is approximately ½ mile north of Highway 60, and 4 miles west of Highway 57.  The area immediately surrounding the facility is urban with a mixture of primarily industrial and commercial zones.

The regulated substance onsite at Danone North America is anhydrous ammonia with a maximum intended inventory of approximately 24,500 pounds.   The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed-loop cycle with no planned or anticipated emissions of ammonia and is used for refrigeration associated with the production and cold storage of dairy products.

The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected and maintained on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

Refrigeration process equipment at the facility operates continuously based on operational + temperature demands.  The compressors and condensers cycle on and off to address system heat load demands during operation.  The primary machinery room houses the compressors and the high pressure receiver vessel (along with auxiliary components), while the glycol heat exchangers and associated surge drum vessel (V4) are located in an adjacent room (Glycol Room).  The recirculator package that includes 2 ammonia pumps and an oil pot is located outside the machinery room near the Water Diffusion Tank.  The condensers are located on the roof, along with the evap

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

WWF Operating Company, LLC (dba Danone North America) recognizes the facilitys responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Danone North America is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program that addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration system at the Danone North America facility in City of Industry, California.

It is Danone North Americas policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the companys goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable facility personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare facility personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

Danone North America draws from several sources and decades of experience + expertise to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  Internal facility personnel with decades of collective experience, the resources of a professional refrigeration contractor, in addition to external risk management consultants all provide guidance to limit the risks of handling ammonia.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.

One of the activities associated with the facilitys safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with Cal-OSHAs Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, CCR Title 8 5189), EPAs Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Pr
